member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.Trend2(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Calculate an n'th order best-fit polynomial, specified X
member.remarks:
Returns coefficients c[0] .. c[n]
Y(x) = c[0] + c[1]x + c[2](x**2) + ... + c[n](x**n)
The X scale is defined by a X VV (see Trend_VV for unitless X).
The polynomial VV length is set to the number of coefficients (order + 1)

Returns coefficients c[0] .. c[n]
Y(x) = c[0] + c[1]x + c[2](x**2) + ... + c[n](x**n)
The X scale is unitless (1 per element), i.e. 0,1,2,3,...
The polynomial VV length is set to the number of coefficients (order + 1)

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.RollingStats(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate a statistic in a rolling window.
member.param: Window size (>0, increased to nearest odd value)
member.remarks:
If the input VVs are not REAL, copies are made to temporary REALs for processing.
If the window size is even, it is increased by 1 so that the output value is put at the exact center index of the window.
Statistics are calculated on the values in a window surrounding the individual data points.
By shrinking the window at the ends, one-sided effects can be eliminated. For instance, if the data is linear to begin with, a rolling mean will not alter the original data. However, if the window size is kept constant, then values near the ends tend to be pulled up or down.
With shrinking, the window is shrunk so that it always has the same width on both sides of the data point under analysis; at the end points the window width is 1, at the next point in it is 3, and so on, until the full width is reached.
The median value is calculated by sorting the valid data in the window, then selecting the middle value. If the number of valid data points is even, then the average of the two central values is returned.
The mode value is defined as the value which occurs most frequently in the data. This value may not even exist, or may not be unique. In this implementation, the following algorithm is used: The valid data in the window is sorted in ascending order. The number of occurrences of each data value is tracked, and if it occurs more times than any value, it becomes the modal value. If all values are different, this procedure returns the smallest value. If two or more values each have the same (maximum) number of occurrences, then the smallest of these values is returned.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.RemoveXYDupIndex(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Remove duplicate samples with the same (X, Y) and update index.
member.remarks: Searches for duplicated (X, Y) locations and removes the duplicates (can be more than just a pair). The Index VV is updated accordingly .i.e if (X,Y) location of Index[0] == Index[1] Index[1] is removed.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.RemoveXYDup(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove/average duplicate samples with the same (X, Y).
member.remarks: Searches for duplicated (X, Y) locations and removes the duplicates (can be more than just a pair). The "Z" values, if defined, are treated according to the value of <define>VV_XYDUP</define>. The returned VVs are shortened to the new length, without duplicates. The Z VV can be set to NULL on input, in which case it is ignored.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.RemoveDup(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove/average duplicate sample pairs from a database.
member.remarks: Created for duplicate sample handling in CHIMERA. On input, a numeric or text VV containing data values, and a sample type VV. Sample pairs have types "1" and "2". This routine searches for types in order "1 2 1 2", and replaces the pair of values in the data VV according to the <define>VV_DUP</define> value. Results for samples out of order, for unmatched pairs, or when the sample type does not equal "1" or "2" remain unchanged.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.RelVarDup(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Estimate relative variance of duplicate sample pairs from a database.
member.remarks: Created for duplicate sample handling in CHIMERA. On input, a numeric or text VV containing data values, and a sample type VV. Sample pairs have types "1" and "2". This routine searches for types in order "1 2 1 2", and calulates the unnormalized relative variance, defined as the sum of the squared differences between duplicates divided by the sum of the squared mean values of the duplicates. (To get the true rel.var., divide by N-1, where N is the number of duplicate pairs used.) Samples out of order, unmatched pairs, or when the sample type does not equal "1" or "2" are ignored.

member.summary: Find the range of hypotenuse values of two VVs.
member.remarks: For each value in the VVs, finds sqrt(dV1*dV1 + dV2*dV2) and returns the min and max values.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.QC(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Quality control on deviation of data from norm in a VV
member.param: Input VV on which to apply quality control Required in <define>GS_DOUBLE</define> or <define>GS_FLOAT</define>
Distance VV (NULL if criterion #2 does not apply). In <define>GS_DOUBLE</define> or <define>GS_FLOAT</define>
Output flag VV with result 0,1,2,3,-1,-2,-3. Required in <define>GS_BYTE</define>
Maximum tolerance/deviation applied to a single reading (criterion #1). <define>GS_R8DM</define> if criterion #1 does not apply. Otherwise, must be positive value including 0.0
Allowed tolerance/deviation over a given distance (next parameter) (criterion #2). <define>GS_R8DM</define> if criterion #2 does not apply. Otherwise, must be positive value including 0.0
The specified distance. <define>GS_R8DM</define> if criterion #2 does not apply. Otherwise, must be positive value excluding 0.0
member.remarks:
This function tests data in input VV against two separate criteria. Each element of the output VV will have one of the following indicators:
========= ============================================================== Indicator Meaning ========= ============================================================== 0 Input data passed both tests --------- -------------------------------------------------------------- 1 The input data and is greater than the nominal value plus maximum tolerance/deviation (Criterion #1) --------- -------------------------------------------------------------- 2 The input data over a specified distance is greater than the nominal value plus allowed tolerance (Criterion #2) --------- -------------------------------------------------------------- 3 The input data failed on above two tests --------- -------------------------------------------------------------- -1 The input data and is less than the nominal value minus maximum tolerance (Criterion #1) --------- -------------------------------------------------------------- -2 The input data over a specified distance is less than the nominal value minus allowed tolerance (Criterion #2) --------- -------------------------------------------------------------- -3 The input data failed on above two tests ========= ==============================================================

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.PickPeak3(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Double,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Find peaks in a VV - method two, returning width and half-amplitude widths.
member.param: [i] X VV used to calculate distance
[i] Y VV used to calculate distance
[i] minimum value to accept (0.0 to find all)
member.remarks:
Uses Method 2 above, but also returns the anomaly width (defined as the distance between the surrounding troughs), and the width at the half-amplitude. The half-amplitude width is calculated in two parts, individually for each side based on the distance from the maximum to the location where the amplitude is mid-way between the maximum and trough.
The returned VVs are packed; no dummies. Instead the indicies of the peak locations are returned.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.PickPeak2(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Find peaks in a VV - method two.
member.param: Returned peak VV, all dummies except peak points.
Base level to accept (0.0 to find all)
member.remarks:
Peaks are the maximum point within a sequence of values in the input VV. Maximum points must be above the base level and have a local amplitude greater than the minimum amplitude specified.
A VV may have to be pre-filtered before finding the peak values.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.PickPeak(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Find peaks in a VV - method one.
member.param: Returned peak VV, all dummies except peak points.
Minimum value to accept (0.0 to find all)
Minimum width to accept (1 to find all)
member.remarks:
Peaks are the maximum point within a sequence of positive values in the input VV. The width is the number of points in the positive sequence.
A VV may have to be pre-filtered before finding the peak values:
Use BPFilt_VVU to smooth the data as required. Use Filter_VVU to apply a Laplace filter "-0.5,1.0,-0.5" to make curvature data.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.OffsetRectangles(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Get non-overlapping offset location for rectangular symbols.
member.remarks:
Often on maps plotted symbols and text overlap each other. This routine accepts of VV of locations and returns a new set of locations offset from the originals, and guaranteed not to overlap, given the size of the original symbols. The returned offset X, Y locations are offset from the original locations by the minimum of a) the input offset, b) the input symbol X or Y size. This is to ensure that the original location is never covered by the offset symbol. In addition, the offset symbol is never place directly below the original location, to make it easier to draw a connecting line.
Care should be taken when choosing the symbol size, because if the point density is too high, all the points will get pushed to the outside edge and your plot will look like a hedgehog (it also takes a lot longer!).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.OffsetCorrectXYZ(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Correct locations based on heading and fixed offset.
member.remarks:
In many applications, measurements are taken with an instrument which is towed behind, or pushed ahead of where the locations are recorded. Use this function to estimate the actual location of the instrument. The method determines the heading along the line, using a "thinned" version of the line. The default degree of thinning is based on the size of the offset; the larger the offset, the greater the distance between sample locations used to construct the thinned lined used for determining headings. The thinned line is splined at a frequency greater than the sample frequency, and the heading at any given point is determined from the vector formed by the closest two points on the splined line. The correction (behind, in front, left or right) is determined with respect to the heading, and added to the original location.
IF this method fails, no dummies, no duplicated locations, no reversals are produced.
The algorithm:
1. Determine average distance between each point = D 2. Default smoothing interval = MAX(2*D, Offset distance) = I 3. Thin input points to be at least the smoothing interval I apart from each other. 4. Smoothly re-interpolate the thinned points at five times the original average distance D. 5. For each input point, calculate the bearing using the nearest points on the smoothed curve

The correction (behind, in front, left or right) is determined with respect to the heading, and added to the original location.
IF this method fails, no dummies, no duplicated locations, no reversals are produced.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.NoiseCheck2(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Like NoiseCheck_VVU, but returns maximum deviation at all points.
member.param: Input VV on which to apply quality control Required in <define>GS_DOUBLE</define> or <define>GS_FLOAT</define>
Output flag VV with result 0 and 1. Required in <define>GS_BYTE</define>
Allowed deviation over a number of data points in input VV (next parameter). Must be >= 0.0
Number of data points in the line segment. Must be > 0
member.remarks:
This function checks vertical deviation of data in an input VV against a moving straight line, where the X-axis value is taken to be the data index, and the Y-axis value is the input data VV value. The straight line is drawn between data points at the ends of the line segment, whose length is an input.
The output flag VV is set to 0 if data point in input VV falls within the deviation for all the moving line segments of which it is a part, otherwise, it will be set to 1.
The output maximum deviation VV contains the maximum deviation at each point for all the moving line segments that it is a part of.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.NoiseCheck(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Check on deviation of data from variable background in a VV
member.param: Input VV on which to apply quality control Required in <define>GS_DOUBLE</define> or <define>GS_FLOAT</define>
Output flag VV with result 0 and 1. Required in <define>GS_BYTE</define>
Allowed deviation over a number of data points in input VV (next parameter). Must be >= 0.0
Number of data points. Must be > 0
member.remarks: This function checks vertical deviation of data in input VV against a moving straight line. The straight line at any time is defined by two extreme points of a data segment. Output VV will be 0 if data point in input VV falls within the deviation, otherwise, it will be 1. Output VV will be 0 if the straight line is vertical.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.FindStringItems(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Searches a VV for items in a second VV, returns indices of those found.
member.param: String VV in which to locate items
String VV Items to search for
Is the first VV already sorted?
Is the second VV already sorted
<define>GS_LONG</define> VV of returned indices into the first LST.
member.remarks:
This is a much more efficient way of determining if items in one VV are found in a second, than by searching repeatedly in a loop. The returned <define>GS_LONG</define> VV contains the same number of items as the "search items" VV, and contains -1 for items where the value is not found, and the index of items that are found. Comparisons are case-tolerant. Non-string VVs are converted to string type VVs (element size 24) internally.
The method requires that the VV items be sorted, and will do so internally. Since the input VVs may already be sorted, the method will run faster if this stage can be skipped.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.DupStats(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Calculate means and differences for duplicate sample pairs
member.remarks: Created for duplicate sample handling in CHIMERA. On input, a numeric VV containing data values, and a sample type VV. Sample pairs have types "1" and "2". This routine searches for types in order "1 2 1 2", and writes the mean values of pairs to the mean value VV, and the differences with the mean (equal values, negative and positive) to the difference VV. Results for samples out of order, for unmatched values, or when the sample type does not equal "1" or "2" are set to dummy.

member.summary: Dummy repeat values in a VV.
member.remarks: Either the first, middle or last point will be left. Use Interp_VVU to interpolate after if desired.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.DummyRangeEx(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Like DummyRangeVVU, with inclusion options for both ends.
member.param: If TRUE, dummy inside the range
If TRUE, include Min in the range.
If TRUE, include Max in the range.
member.remarks: If the Inside flag is TRUE, values within the specified range are set to dummy. If the inside flag is FALSE, values outside the range are set to dummy. If the Inclusive flag is TRUE, then dMin and dMax are considered part of the range. If it is FALSE, then < or > are used, and dMin and dMax lie outside the range.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.Distance3D(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Create a cumulative distance VV from X, Y and Z VVs
member.remarks: The output VV is the length of the shortest X,Y or Z input VV. Any values with dummies are ignored - the distance at that point is equal to the distance at the previous valid point. The returned VV is the cumulative straight-line distance between the points. No re-sampling is performed. VVs of any type are supported.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.ClipToDetectLimit(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Apply detection limit clipping of data.
member.remarks:
Flow:
1. If auto-converting negatives, then all negative values are replaced by -0.5*value, and detection limit is ignored.
2. If not auto-converting negatives, and the detection limit is not <define>rDUMMY</define>, then values less than the detection limit are converted to one-half the detection limit.
This function is identical to ClipToDetectLimit_CHIMERA.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.AverageRepeat2Ex(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32)
member.summary: Average repeat values based on 2 reference channels.
member.remarks: Repeated values in the reference VV will be set to the mean, median, minimum or maximum value in the data VV. The first value in the data VV will be reset and subsequent data VV values will be dummied out. Data is processed only to the minimum length of the input VV lengths. Both the reference VV values must repeat for the averaging to occur. This version is useful for averaging on repeated (X,Y) locations.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.AverageRepeat2(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Average repeat values based on 2 reference channels.
member.remarks: Repeated values in the reference VV will be averaged in the data VV. The first value in the data VV will be set to the average and subsequent data VV values will be dummied out. Data is processed only to the minimum length of the input VV lengths. Both the reference VV values must repeat for the averaging to occur. This version is useful for averaging on repeated (X,Y) locations.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.AverageRepeatEx(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32)
member.remarks: Repeated values in the reference VV will be set to the mean, median, minimum or maximum value in the data VV. For minimum and maximum, the index in the data VV containing the minimum or maximum value is retained, and the other repeated values are dummied out. For mean and median, the first value in the data VV will be reset and subsequent data VV values will be dummied out. Data is processed only to the minimum length of the input VV lengths.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CVVU.AverageRepeat(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.remarks: Repeated values in the reference VV will be averaged in the data VV. The first value in the data VV will be set to the average and subsequent data VV values will be dummied out. Data is processed only to the minimum length of the input VV lengths.

member.name: T:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CUNC
member.summary: This library is not a class. Use the UNC library functions to work with Unicode characters and strings. Since version 6.2 all strings are represented internally in the the GX engine as UTF-8. The character set concept was discarded as a way to work with characters that does not fall within the normal ASCII range 0x01-0x7F. The utilities here aids with any new functionality that is now possible (e.g. an expanded symbol range with TrueType fonts).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTIN.RangeXY(System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Find the range in X and Y of the TINned region.
member.remarks: The TINned range is the range of X and Y covered by the TIN triangles. It can thus be less than the full X and Y range of the nodes themselves, if a full convex hull is not calculated.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTIN.NearestVV(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Interp TINned values using the nearest neighbour.
member.remarks:
The TIN have been created using max length = <define>rDUMMY</define> to ensure that the TIN has a convex hull (otherwise the routine that locates the triangle for a given location may fail). The TIN must also have been created using the Z values. Values located outside the convex hull are set to <define>rDUMMY</define>.
Within each voronoi triangle, the Z value of node closest to the input X,Y location is returned.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTIN.LinearInterpVV(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Interp TINned values using the linear interpolation
member.remarks:
The TIN have been created using max length = <define>rDUMMY</define> to ensure that the TIN has a convex hull (otherwise the routine that locates the triangle for a given location may fail). The TIN must also have been created using the Z values. Values located outside the convex hull are set to <define>rDUMMY</define>.
The values are set assuming that each TIN triangle defines a plane.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTIN.iTriangles
member.summary: Returns the number of triangles in the TIN.
member.returns: The number of triangles in the TIN

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTIN.InterpVV(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Interp TINned values using the natural neighbour method.
member.remarks:
The TIN have been created using max length = <define>rDUMMY</define> to ensure that the TIN has a convex hull (otherwise the routine that locates the triangle for a given location may fail). The TIN must also have been created using the Z values. Values located outside the convex hull are set to <define>rDUMMY</define>. The method is based on the following paper:
Sambridge, M., Braun, J., and McQueen, H., 1995, Geophysical parameterization and interpolation of irregular data using natural neighbours: Geophysical Journal International, 122 p. 837-857.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTIN.iNodes

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTIN.iLocateTriangle(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Get the index of the triangle containing X, Y.
member.remarks:
Index returned begins at 0, but could be negative.
-1: If X,Y is not contained in a triangle (or triangle not found)
-2: If the location is on an edge This is for "fall-back" purposes only.
Frequently edge positions are located as being part of a triangle, so do not rely on this result to determine if a node position is on an edge.
-3: If the location is a vertex. This is for "fall-back" purposes only in the code. Normal operation is to include a node position inside a triangle, so do not rely on this result to determine if a node position is input.
member.returns: The index of the triangle containing X, Y.

The join information is returned in three VVs.

member.name: T:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTIN
member.summary: The TIN class calculates the Delaunay triangulation of the positions in a database. This is the "best" set of triangles that can be formed from irregularly distributed points. The serialized TIN files can be used for gridding using the Tin-based Nearest Neighbour Algorithm, or for plotting the Delaunay triangles or Voronoi cells to a map.

member.name: T:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CTC
member.summary: The TC object is used in gravitational modelling to create a terrain correction grid from a topography grid. This is accomplished with a call first to Grregter_TC, which determines the terrain correction from an input topography grid, then to Grterain_TC, which calculates the actual corrections at the input positions.

The STK class is used for plotting a single data profile in an MVIEW. The MSTK class (see MSTK) is used to plot multiple STK objects to a single map.
Use AddSTK_MSTK fuction to create a STK object before using functions in this file
SEE MSTK FILE FOR DETAILED DESCRIPTIONS OF ALL FUNCTION PARAMETERS.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSHP.Create(System.String,System.Int32)
member.remarks:
The file name is used to create the various files. The file type and extension are added:
e.g. "filename.shp", "filename.dbf"
The following geometry types are currently supported:
Type Required geometry function.
<define>SHP_GEOM_TYPE_POINT</define> SetPoint_SHP <define>SHP_GEOM_TYPE_ARC</define> SetArc_SHP <define>SHP_GEOM_TYPE_POLYGON</define> SetPolygon_SHP
<define>SHP_GEOM_TYPE_POINTZ</define> SetPointZ_SHP <define>SHP_GEOM_TYPE_ARCZ</define> SetArcZ_SHP <define>SHP_GEOM_TYPE_POLYGONZ</define> SetPolygonZ_SHP

member.remarks: The mineral channel is needed in order to adjust the total with the Fe Corrected Ferric and Ferrous values, and these require a mineral for their identification. If none is provided, mineral "X" (unknown) is assumed.

member.summary: Set the mask channel ON or OFF.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.SetChannelUnits(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB)
member.summary: Set units for oxides (%) and elements (ppm)
member.remarks: If the channel units are already set, then they are not changed. Oxide channels are identified from the Semplot_Oxides.csv file. Trace elements are identified from the periodic table of the elements, except for "Y", if it is the current Y channel.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.SetChannelOrder(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CLST)
member.remarks:
Sets channel order as follows:
Sample_No X and Y Locations Mineral Grain_No Position (e.g. center, edge etc.) Grain Morph Oxides (in the order they appear in Semplot_Oxides.csv) Trace Elements (Ordered as in the periodic table) Total Mask IsPlotted (flag set when a value is plotted) Other channels
Channel order is set for all "RawData" groups.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.SelectPoly(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CMVIEW,System.String,System.String,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPLY,System.Int32)
member.summary: Select data from a polygonal area on a map.
member.param: Polygon to select from, in the view coordinates.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.ResetUsedChannel(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB)
member.remarks: This function is called before one or a series of plots to initialize the "Plotted" channel in all the selected lines to dummy values. As the plots are created, those points used in the plot are set to 1, so that at the end the database records which values have been plotted. This information can then be used to make a symbol legend. If the "Plotted" channel does not exist, it is created, associated, loaded, and filled with dummies.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.RePlotSymbolLegend(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CMVIEW)
member.summary: Replot a symbol legend in a view.
member.remarks: Searches the VIEW REG for information on a previously created legend, and if it finds that info, replots the Legend, using the current data, group key etc.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.Replot(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.String,System.String,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CMAP,System.String)
member.summary: Replot an existing SEMPLOT plot based on current data.
member.param: Mineral channel (can be "" for raw data)
member.remarks:
Note that the selection of data in the current DB is used to replot the map.
Call "ResetUsedChannel_SEMPLOT" prior to this function in order to track the values actually plotted.
Call InitGroupSymbolsUsed_SEMPLOT prior to this function to reset recording of the symbols used in plotting (for legends etc).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.PropSymb(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CMAP,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.remarks: Replots map using proportional symbols

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.PlotSymbolLegend(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CMVIEW,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Plot a symbol legend in a view.
member.remarks: This function depends on InitGroupSymbolsUsed_SEMPLOT before the plot for which this legend is created is made. The symbols and groups to use in the legend are stored to a database blob after the plot is made. These values are recovered by this function to make the legend at the specified location.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.Plot(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Plot an XYPlot or TriPlot based on the template.
member.param: Mineral channel (can be "" for raw data)
Map open mode; one of MAP_WRITEXXX (see map.gxh)
member.remarks:
The "Components" and "Parameters" groups in the INI file are used. Only values with mask values of 1 are plotted, if the mask channel is specified.
Call "ResetUsedChannel_SEMPLOT" prior to this function in order to track the values actually plotted.
Call InitGroupSymbolsUsed_SEMPLOT prior to this function to reset recording of the symbols used in plotting (for legends etc).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.OverlayLST(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CLST,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Fill a list with the available plot overlay names
member.remarks: Looks first in user\etc, then in \etc. See <define>SEMPLOT_EXT</define> definitions above for which files to look for.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.NewTemplate(System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Create a new XYPlot or TriPlot template.
member.param: Template to use as a model (can be "")
member.remarks:
The new template is written to the user\etc directory, with the file extension "semfilter". The template contains a parameter identifying it as an XY or Triplot.
Model Template: Looks first in user\etc, then in \etc. Looks first for file prefix "semtemplate" then "xyt" or "tri"
Because there are so many shared parameters, it is possible to use an XYPlot template as a model for a TriPlot, and vica-verca, with few complications. (e.g. needing to define a "Z" component)

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.NewFilter(System.String,System.String)
member.param: Filter to use as a model (can be "")
member.remarks: Creates a new, empty filter file in the user\etc directory

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.MineralID(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Identify minerals from the oxide channels.
member.param: Maximum residual value (in % of the total oxide)
member.remarks: Finds the best mineral matching the composition for each row of oxide values. Works using linear programming and the simplex method to maximize the oxides used to create each of the possible output minerals. The mineral leaving the least leftover is selected, as long as the residual (measured as a percent of the total) is less than or equal to the input value.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.iViewType(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CMAP,System.String)
member.summary: Test to see if a view is an XYPlot or Triplot view.
member.remarks: First checks the view name to see if it starts with "XYplt_" or "Triplt_". Failing that it looks in the view REG for a value for "Components.Type", which will be either "XYPlot" or "TriPlot". If the view does not appear to be an XYPlot or a TriPlot view, the function returns <define>SEMPLOT_PLOT_UNKNOWN</define>.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.iTemplateType(System.String)
member.summary: Create a new XYPlot or TriPlot template.

member.summary: Initializes memory of symbols used in plotting.
member.remarks: Maintains a list of the symbols used in plotting. Call before Plotting one or more legends - symbols are accumulated. PlotSymbolLegend_SEMPLOT uses this information to create a legend.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.ImportDatabaseADO(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Generate a template file for importing semplot databases.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.ImportBIN(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Import blocked binary or archive ASCII data
member.remarks:
This wrapper is for SEMPLOT, and does not require the import licence.
1. Binary import templates have extension .I2 by convention. See BINARY.I2 for a description of the template format. Archive import templates have extension .I3 by convention. See ARCHIVE.I3 for a description of the template format.
2. Both the import template and data file must exist.
3. If a line already exists in the database, a new version is created unless a line name is passed in. In this case, the specified name is used and the imported channels on the previous line will be destroyed.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.iEditFilter(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Edit and create filter on channel values
member.returns:
-1 - Cancel - Edits to filter discarded.
0 - Normal Return. Edits saved to filter file.
1 - Apply filter to current data only
2 - Remove filter - If removing filtered data, just restore the data to the Min/Pos data otherwise set the mask channel to 1.
Re-entry code. If not <define>iDUMMY</define>, what to do inside the filter after going back in. Returned on exit, used on next input.
0 - Nothing. Don't need to go back into this function again. 1 - Edit the filter.
Notes New and edited filters are stored in user\etc in files with the file extension ".semfilter" If a file for the specified filter does not exist, then a new filter by that name will be created.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CSEMPLOT.FilterLST(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CLST)
member.summary: Fill a LST with existing SEMPLOT filters
member.remarks: "Supplied" filters are stored in \etc, while user-edited and new filters are stored in user\etc. This function finds all files with the extension ".semfilter", first in user\etc, then in \etc, and adds the file names (without the extension) to the LST. The name with the extension is stored as the value. The LST is cleared first.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.rMaximumTerrainSteepness(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compute the Maximum Steepness of a topography Pager
member.remarks: Calculates forward-looking slopes SX and SY in the X and Y directions using pager locations (ix, iy), (ix+size, iy), (ix, iy+isize) and returns SX*SX + SY*SY. The values in the last "size" rows and columns are not processed. The wrapper was created for testing and development purposes.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PCVarimax(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary: Perform the Kaiser Varimax transformation on pr. comp. loadings
member.param: Principal component loadings (input) (N by M, M<=N)
Rotated principal component loadings (returned) (N by L, L<=M)
member.remarks: Rotates the principal components using the Kaiser's varimax scheme to move move each factor axis to positions so that projections from each variable on the factor axes are either near the extremities or near the origin. Pagers must be type <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PCTransform(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32)
member.remarks: Works on columns of the PG. Forward direction: Applies the selected transform to the data. Backward direction: Applies the inverse transform to the data. The detection limits are input with a VV. In the forward transform, data values less than the detection limit are set to the limit. The factor limits are input with a VV. In the forward transform, data values greater than the maximum values are set to the maximum.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PCStandardize2(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove/Replace mean and standard deviation, subset values.
member.param: Mask VV for data selection (forward only)
member.remarks: Like PCStandardize_PGU, except that not all the values are included in the calculation of the means and standard deviations. The inclusion is controlled by a mask VV, The rows where the mask is dummy are not included in the calculation, but ALL the values are standardized.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PCStandardize(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Int32)
member.remarks: Works on columns of the PG.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PCScores(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary: Compute the principal component scores from the standardized data.
member.param: Principal component loadings (input) (N by L, L<=N)
Principal component scores (returned) (M by L, L<=N)
member.remarks: t -1 Forms the product X Ap (Ap Ap), where X is the standardized data matrix, and Ap is the matrix of principal component loadings (see PCLoadings_PGU). The loadings must be input, and can be calculated by calling PCLoadings_PGU. Pagers and VVs must be type <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PCLoadings2(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary: Same as PCLoading_PGU, but input correlation matrix.
member.remarks: See PCLoadings_PGU.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PCLoadings(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary: Compute the principal component loadings from the standardized data.
member.remarks: Works on columns of the PG. Calculates the correlation matrix from the columns of the standardized data, then computes the eigen values and eigenvectors of the correlation matrix. The loadings are the eigenvectors, ordered by descending eigenvalues, scaled by the square root of the eigenvalues. The returned pager must be sized the same as the input pager. Correlations are performed using "<define>PGU_CORR_SIMPLE</define>", so if you want Pearson correlations, or wish to use a modified correlation matrix, use PCLoadings2_PGU and input the correlation matrix directly.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PCCommunality(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.param: Input pager of the principal components
member.remarks: Calculate communalities (sums of the squares of the column values in each row) Pagers and VVs must be type <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.SVRecompose(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,System.Double,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary: Reconstitute the original matrix from an SVD.
member.param: Minimum weight to use (Dummy for all)
member.remarks:
The matrix is input as an N rows (data) by M columns (variables) PG. On return, the matrix is decomposed to A = U * W * Vt. If M<N, then an error will be registered. In this case, augment the "A" PG with rows of zero values. The input matrices must be A[M,N], U[M.N] and V[N,N]. The length of the W VV is set by sSVDecompose_PGU to N. The Pagers must be type <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>.
Terminates if:
U is not M by N. (Taken from size of A) V is not N by N. (Taken from #columns in A). PGs, VV are not <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>.
Dummies are treated as 0 values.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.SVDecompose(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary: Do a singular value decomposition on a matrix stored as a PG
member.param: Input A matrix, M data (rows), N variables (columns)
member.remarks:
The matrix is input as an N rows (data) by M columns (variables) PG. On return, the matrix is decomposed to A = U * W * Vt. If M<N, then an error will be registered. In this case, augment the "A" PG with rows of zero values.
The input matrices must be A[M,N], U[M.N] and V[N,N]. The length of the W VV is set by sSVD_PGU to N.
The Pagers must be type <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>.
Terminates if:
U is not M by N. (Taken from size of A) V is not N by N. (Taken from #columns in A). PGs, VV are not <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.MatrixVectorMult(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Multiply a VV by a pager like a matrix*vector multiply.
member.remarks:
The matrix is input as an M rows (data) by N columns (variables) PG. The vector must be of length N. The output VV is set to length M. The PG and VVs must be type <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>.
Terminates if:
Matrices, VV are not expected sizes (taken from U) PGs are not <define>GS_DOUBLE</define>.
Dummies are treated as 0 values.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.MatrixMult(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,System.Int32,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,System.Int32,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary: Multiply two pagers as if they were matrices.

TRUE (1) if V should be transposed before multiplication
member.remarks: The matrices must be correctly dimensioned, taking into account whether transposition should occur before multiplication. The input matrices are not altered on output (even if transposition is requested). Assertions if: Matrices are not expected sizes Dummies are treated as 0 values.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.LUDecomp(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Perform an LU decomposition on a square pager.
member.param: LU decomposition (may be same pager as input)
member.remarks: The L and U matrix are both contained in the returned pager; The "L" matrix is composed of the sub-diagonal elements of the output pager, as well as "1" values on the diagonal. The "U" matrix is composed of the diagonal elements (sub-diagonal elements set to 0). This is an "in-place" operation, and set up so that the input and output pagers may be the same handle. (If they are different, the input pager remains unchanged). The LU decomposition, and the permutation vector are used for LUBackSub_PGU. Pagers must be type <define>GS_DOUBLE</define> and the permutation vector type INT

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.LUBackSub(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Solve a linear system using LU decomposition and back-substitution.
member.remarks: Solves the system Ax = b for a given b, using the LU decomposition of the matrix a The LU decomposition and the permutation vector are obtained from LUBackSub_PGU. Pagers and VVs must be type <define>GS_DOUBLE</define> except for the permutation vector, which should be INT

member.summary: Find eigenvalues, eigenvectors of a real symmetric matrix.
member.remarks: The number of rows must equal the number of columns. Eienvalues, vectors are sorted in descending order.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.CorrelationMatrix(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary: Find the correlations between columns in a matrix
member.remarks: The input matrix is M rows by N columns. The returned matrix is a symmetric N by N matrix whose elements are the normalized dot products of the columns of the input matrix with themselves. The elements take on values from 0 (orthogonal) to 1 (parallel).

member.summary:
Set numeric values in a pager based on an index pager with translation VV.

The items in the input data VV are inserted into the output PG using the indices in the index PG.
This function is useful when converting a thematic voxel, which is type <define>GS_LONG</define> and contains indices into its own internal TPAT object, and you provide a numeric mapping VV, calculated using SetupTranslateToNumericVV_TPAT.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.RefFile(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,System.String)
member.summary: Create a reference file (boolean mask flag) from pager.
member.remarks:
A reference file is a binary file with the following format:
The first 8 bytes are the pager dimensions NX and NY as longs. The remaining bits, one bit per pager cell - (NX * NY)/8 bytes are zero where the pager is dummy, and 1 where the pager is defined.
The reference file is used in various operations where it is necessary to mask some output to the original defined cells.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.PeakednessGrid(System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Create peakedneess grid from input grid.
member.remarks: This function creates a peakedneess grid from input grid. Radius, is the maximum radius at which the value of the parent pixel is compared to the value of surrounding pixels. percent_lesser, is used to indicate the percentage of pixels at each radii smaller than or equal to Radius that must have value lower than the parent pixel in order to call that radius true or equal to 1. Description: For each pixel in the grid a series of radii are evaluated from 1 to Radius. If the percentage of pixels for a given radius is less than percent_lesser the parent pixel receives an additional 1. For examples if the Radius is set to 5 and the percent_lesser is set to 70%. And radius 1 = 90%, radius 2 = 85%, radius 3 = 75%, radius 4 = 70% and radius 5 = 65% then the parent pixel would receive 1+1+1+1+0 = 4. Use: This function is useful in isolating the anomaly peaks in data that has a large value range for anomalies. For example the 1 mV anomaly could quite possibly have the same representation as the 100 mV anomaly using this function.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.Peakedness(System.String,System.Int32,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Find all peaks in peakedneess grid pager

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.NumericToThematic(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG)
member.summary:
NumericToThematic_PGU Set index values in a pager based on a numeric pager with translation VV.
Returns Nothing
member.remarks:
The values in the input data VV represent the center-of-range values of unique properties with indices 0 to N-1, where N is the number of items in the input VV.
This VV is sorted from smallest to largest, and each value in in the input numeric PG is tested to see into which range it goes. The closest range value for each item is used, so the half-way point is the dividing point. The top and bottom-most range widths are determined by the "inside half-width" to the nearest range.
The INDEX of the closest range is then inserted into the output PG, so it can be used in a thematic voxel (for instance).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.IDWGriddingVV(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CREG)

member.summary: Apply 5x5 symmetric convolution filter to a PG.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.FillValue(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,System.Double)
member.summary: Set all values in a pager to a single value.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CPGU.Fill(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CPG,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Replace all dummies in a pager by predict values.
member.param: Roll off weighting option: 1 - linear, 2 - square
dRollBase - the value to roll off to, <define>GS_R8DM</define> for roll off to mean value line by line.
lRollDist - (at unit of cell dist.) for roll-off. 0 for no roll of, -1 for the default: 2 times of min. dummy edge dim.
lMxf - max. filter length. -1 for no max. entropy. 0 for the default of MIN(minimum dummy edge dim, 32).
lMxp - max. pred. sample 0 for the default of 2*lMxf.
dAmpLmt - limit (abs. value) amplitudes to this level. Amplitudes are limited starting at half this value. <=0.0 for no amp limit.
dEdgeLmt - limit edge (abs. value) amplitudes to this level. <0.0 for no edge limit.
lEdgeWidth - within this dist. (at unit of cell size) for amp. limited. -1 for no edge limit. 0 for the default of minimum dummy edge dim.
iNPass - number of time to pass smooth filter
sRefFil - reference file for smooth filter flag.

Format of the input string:
Map group name + " ( " + X channel name + " , " + Y channel name + " )"
for example, string "DATA ( DIST , MAG )" indicates a map group name of DATA, X channel name of DIST and Y channel name of MAG.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CIP.LocateContributingElectrodes3D(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Double)

member.param: Rx1 Z channel (assume zero elevation if not specified)
Rx2 Z channel (assume zero elevation if not specified)
Tx1 Z channel (assume zero elevation if not specified)
Tx2 Z channel (assume zero elevation if not specified)
member.remarks: Sets up an EXT object in the database that captures row/line change events and plots the electrodes for the selected row on an accompanying 3D view. The EXT object is removed by running LaunchRemoveContributingElectrodesEXTTool_IPGUI. This EXT is not serialized, so it is also removed if the database is closed (since this is not the normal behaviour expected from a database).

This EXT is not serialized, so it is also removed if the database is closed (since this is not the normal behaviour expected from a database).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CIP.SetImportMode(System.Int32)
member.summary: When importing data to a line, set append/overwrite mode.
member.remarks: By default, importing data overwrites existing data. Call this function before doing the import in order to append imported data to existing data. "Short" data channels will be dummied to the existing data length before the new data is appended.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CIP.SetImportLine(System.String)
member.summary: Set the line name for some imports.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CIP.RecalculateZ(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB)
member.remarks: The "Z" channel values are calculated as follows: If the "Topo" value is defined, then Z = Topo - 0.5*N*A, where "N" is the N-spacing, and A is the A-spacing. If the Topography is not defined, then it is assumed to be equal to 0.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CIP.RecalculateEx(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.Int32)
member.summary: Recalculate derived channel values, with option for including/excluding location calculations.
member.remarks: See Recalculate_IP. This version allows you to suppress the recalculation of the current X, Y and Z channel values from the station locations.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CIP.Recalculate(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB)
member.remarks:
This function recalculates "derived" channel values from "core" data.
1. Recalculates the "STN" and "N" channels, using the TX1, TX2, RX1 and RX2 channels (depending on the system). 2. Recalculates the apparent resistivity "ResCalc", average "IP_Avg" and metal factor "MF" channels 3. Recalculates the "X" and "Y" channels. One of these will be equal to "STN", the other to the internally stored line number for the current line. 4. Recalculate the "Z" channel, based on the current "Topo" channel, and the "N" values.
Warning: If you make a change to an electrode location, you would have to call Recalculate_IP, then recalculate "Topo" (since the X and Y values would have changed), then call RecalculateZ_IP, since "Z" values are based on "Topo" values.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CHTTP.Create(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This method creates a connection to an HTTP server
member.remarks:
An OM user has the ability to control access and verification of access to servers over the Internet. A GX Developer has no way to change the users choice of access. This is to prevent the creation of GX's that may be dangerous or may be used to collect information without the knowledgede of the user.
If the specified URL is restricted from access by the user, the create function will fail.
If the specified URL has not been accessed by this user before, or if the user has this site on "Verify", the user will be presented with a dialog requiring verification before communication can begin. The user may choose to change the server site to a full "Trust" relationship, in which case the verification message will not reappear unless the site is explicitly changed back to verify or is restricted.
If you intend your GX to communicate with a server without verification, you must instruct your user to change their trust relationship with your server to "Trusted". Your user will have the opportunity to do so the first time a script is run.

member.name: T:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CHTTP
member.summary: Connect to an Internet Server using HTTP.

member.summary: Two-panel selection, items not sorted alphabetically.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.iTwoPanelSelection(System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CLST,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CLST,System.String)
member.param: The the message box will display in front of.
member.remarks:
Takes as input two LSTs, one contains all available items, the second currently selected items. These are processed, and in the left panel are displayed all items in the first LST not in the selection LST, and on the right all items in the first LST which are in the selection LST. (Items in the selection LST NOT in the first LST are ignored). Once the user has finalized the selections, the final selections are returned in the selection LST.
Selections and display are based on the <define>LST_ITEM_NAME</define> part of the LST item, but on export both the <define>LST_ITEM_NAME</define> and <define>LST_ITEM_VALUE</define> elements of the selected items from the first LST are transferred to the second list for output.
The sConvertToCSV_LST and sConvertFromCSV_LST functions in lst.h can be used to convert the selection LSTs to forms that can be stored and retrieved from GX parameters (or REG or INI, etc.).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.iTwoPanelSelection(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CLST,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CLST,System.String)
member.remarks:
Takes as input two LSTs, one contains all available items, the second currently selected items. These are processed, and in the left panel are displayed all items in the first LST not in the selection LST, and on the right all items in the first LST which are in the selection LST. (Items in the selection LST NOT in the first LST are ignored). Once the user has finalized the selections, the final selections are returned in the selection LST.
Selections and display are based on the <define>LST_ITEM_NAME</define> part of the LST item, but on export both the <define>LST_ITEM_NAME</define> and <define>LST_ITEM_VALUE</define> elements of the selected items from the first LST are transferred to the second list for output.
The sConvertToCSV_LST and sConvertFromCSV_LST functions in lst.h can be used to convert the selection LSTs to forms that can be stored and retrieved from GX parameters (or REG or INI, etc.).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.IiODBCFileConnect(System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window,System.String,System.String@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the connection string for a file database as well as optional table name and FileUsage attribute
member.param: The the message box will display in front of.
File Usage (0 - ODBC drivers not queried, 1 - Directory containing tables, 2 - File containing tables)
Table name of file (returned if plUsage==1)
member.remarks: If the file extension is "mdb" or "xls" then a Microsoft Access or Excel database is assumed. Otherwise, a dialog appears listing the installed ODBC file database drivers. If the driver takes a directory as a database (FileUsage==1) the table name is also returned. This is needed because the table name may or may not include the file extension.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.iImportTemplateSQLADO(System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Create template to import an external database table; provide query.

External database connection string (Blank for OLEDB Wizard)
SQL selection query to run on database
Name of Oasis table to create

This is similar to iImportDatabaseSQL_GUI, but dispenses with the dialog offering a selection of queries. Instead, the user supplies the query as a string.
This function DOES NOT import the table itself, but creates an import template which may be used to import the data (see ImportADO_DU).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.iImportDatabaseSQLADO(System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create template to import an external database table, created using SQL (New ADO Version).
member.param: The the message box will display in front of.
External database connection string (Blank for OLEDB Wizard)
Text file with SQL queries to use, ("" - get from database)
member.remarks:
This is used to build an Oasis montaj group (line) from one or more database tables and fields, by selecting from one or more SQL selection queries. The list of queries is read from a text file with the following syntax:
Query_Name_1 Query... Query... (continued) ... ... END_QUERY Query_Name_2 etc.
Each query has a title line, the query itself, then the "END_QUERY" line to finish. The title of a subsequent query is on the line after an "END_QUERY" line.
If the text file parameter is left blank (""), then selection queries in the database itself are listed. In addition to the pre-defined queries, there is a "User Defined" query which may be filled in by the user.
This function DOES NOT import the table itself, but creates an import template which may be used to import the data (see ImportDAO_DU).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.iImportDatabaseSQLADO(System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Create template to import an external database table, created using SQL (New ADO Version).
member.param: The the message box will display in front of.
External database connection string (Blank for OLEDB Wizard)
Text file with SQL queries to use, ("" - get from database)
member.remarks:
This is used to build an Oasis montaj group (line) from one or more database tables and fields, by selecting from one or more SQL selection queries. The list of queries is read from a text file with the following syntax:
Query_Name_1 Query... Query... (continued) ... ... END_QUERY Query_Name_2 etc.
Each query has a title line, the query itself, then the "END_QUERY" line to finish. The title of a subsequent query is on the line after an "END_QUERY" line.
If the text file parameter is left blank (""), then selection queries in the database itself are listed. In addition to the pre-defined queries, there is a "User Defined" query which may be filled in by the user.
This function DOES NOT import the table itself, but creates an import template which may be used to import the data (see ImportDAO_DU).

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.IiImportDrillDatabaseODBC(System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window,System.String@,System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32,System.Int32@,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CREG)
member.summary: Generate a template file for importing drill holes from ODBC database data.
member.param: The the message box will display in front of.
member.remarks: If the input connection string is empty (""), then the ODBC connection dialogs will appear (e.g. to connect to a machine database) before the import wizard is run. The connect string used for this connection is then returned. This string can then be used on input to skip the ODBC connection dialogs and go straight to the Wholeplot import wizard. Because the name of the database is not necessarily known, the template name is created from the name of the table opened - e.g. "HOLELOCATION.i4".

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.IiCustomFileForm(System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: General file Open/Save Form for Multiple/Single file selections and custom filter capability
member.param: The the message box will display in front of.
Where the file name(s) is returned
Size of the File Name Buffer
Allow Multiple file selections = TRUE Single file selections = FALSE
member.remarks: Remember to make the string size big enough for multiple file selections. In the case of multiple selections the names will be separated by a semicolon and only the first file will contain the full path.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.IiCumulativePercent(System.String@,System.Int32,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CITR)
member.summary: Define a percent-based ITR of up to 12 zones.
member.param: Buffer size for the file name
member.remarks:
The ITR values are interpreted as cumulative percent values, using the "PERCENT=1" value in the ITR's REG.
Note that processes using ITRs do not automatically know to convert between percent values and "actual" data values. The REG "PERCENT" value is simply a flag to indicate to a user that the values are intended to be in the range from 0 < x < 100. The ITR should not, therefore, be applied directly to data unless that data is already given in percent.
If the file name is defined on input, the initial ITR will be loaded from it. If it is left blank, a default 5-color transform with The color transform file name is used as the default when the save button is pushed, and is updated both after the load and save buttons are pushed by the value input or selected by the user.

The ITR should not, therefore, be applied directly to data unless that data is already given in percent.

member.summary: Define an ITR of up to 12 zones, with file load/save buttons.

Buffer size for the file name
member.remarks: The statistics object is required in order to determine data ranges, percentiles, etc. Create it using CreateExact_ST, or be sure to enable histogram statistics. The color transform file name is used as the default when the save button is pushed, and is updated both after the load and save buttons are pushed by the value input or selected by the user.

member.summary: Return the directory path for value of <define>GS_DIRECTORY</define>.
member.param: Size of the directory path buffer
member.remarks:
Works along with the IGetFileFilter_GUI function. Note that most values of FILE_FILTER_XXX will return <define>GS_DIRECTORY_NONE</define>, and give the current workspace directory.
This function is useful for constuction open/save dialog file filters, especially in GX.Net functions.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.IGetFileFilter(System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32,System.String@,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Return the defined filter, mask, extension and directory for an input filter.
member.param: Size of the file filter buffer
Size of the file mask buffer
Size of the file extension buffer
member.remarks:
Returns the four parts of the file filter; e.g. for <define>FILE_FILTER_GDB</define> it returns:
Filter: "Database (*.gdb)" Mask: "*.gdb" Extension: "gdb" Directory: "<define>GS_DIRECTORY_NONE</define>"
This function is useful for constuction open/save dialog file filters, especially in GX.Net functions.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGUI.iDatamineType(System.String,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns the type of a Datamine file.
member.remarks:
Often, a Datamine file can be opened a number of different ways (e.g. as a string file or a as wireframe (point) file. The following function checks to see if there is a choice to be made between types supported by Geosoft for import. If not, it just returns the original type "hint" from Datamine. If there is a choice, it puts up a dialog with the choices for the user to pick from. Do a bit-wise AND with the returned type to determine the file type (or the type selected).
Currently supported overlapping types/choices:
dmString dmWireframePoint

member.param: Ask about <define>C_TRANSPARENT</define> if white is selected (1: yes, 0: no)?
member.remarks:
Color value is set on input, and new value returned. If the input color type is <define>C_TRANSPARENT</define>, then the color is set to white, if any other type is input the output is guaranteed to be of the same type.
If no_col is 1, then on exit, if white is selected, the user is prompted: 'Do you want white (Yes) or "None" (No) ?' and the color is converted as requested. If this is not the case, the <define>C_TRANSPARENT</define> is converted to white (if "Ok" is selected) and no choice is offered.

member.summary: Get Euler solutions of depth from VVs and grids.
member.remarks:
All VVs must be REAL
The output X and Y values are the same as the inputs, except if <define>PEAKEULER_XY_FIT</define> is selected. All other output values are set to dummy if:
a) The input X or Y is a dummy b) The derived window size is a dummy. c) The derived solution is outside the range d) The solution is invalid (singular matrix)

member.summary: Calculate the corner point locations for a Maxwell Plate.
member.remarks: This routine calculates the corner locations of plates defined in the Maxwell Plate program, given the top-center location and plate geometry parameters.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGU.MagneticTiltDepth(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Calculate the depth of magnetic sources based on the tilt depth method by Ahmed Salem et al.
member.remarks: Tilt-Depth is a magnetic depth estimation method that lends itself to rapid mapping of sedimentary basins without the complexity of unraveling the depth solutions from methods that give multiple solutions (e.g. Euler deconvolution). Reference: Sedimentary basins reconnaissance using the magnetic Tilt-Depth method by Ahmed Salem et al. Exploration Geophysics, 2010, 41, 198-209. Rick Blakely & Gerry Connard have extended and improved this method, as have other authors. The 0-value contour of the tilt derivative grid is sampled to a new database, and the horizontal derivative grid is sampled at those locations. The inverse of the horizontal derivative values are output to the Tilt_Depth channel.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGU.LagDAARC500GPS(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Lag the GPS fid values for the DAARC500 import.
member.param: GPS fid values (<define>GS_DOUBLE</define>, altered on return)
member.remarks: The fiducial times recorded for the GPS in the RMS Instrument DAARC500 are delayed, and associated with the "wrong" fid value. They should actually be moved to the previous fid value in the mag data where the event flag is non-zero.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGU.ImportP190(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.String,System.String,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CWA)
member.summary: Import navigation data in the P190 format.
member.param: Single letter code, e.g. "C", "E", "S", "T" or "V", or blank for all records.
member.remarks: Imports the data, and, if projection information is included set the "X" and "Y" channel projection info. (Note: the last file imported always takes precedence). Different record types are imported to separate lines, but in the same order as in the file. Data in existing lines is overwritten. If the record type is specified, only records beginning with that letter are imported, otherwise all records (except for the header "H" records) are imported.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CGU.GeometricsQC(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CWA,System.String,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.summary: Correct reading positions in a database.
member.param: Database line number. For output to log file only
Tolerance defined as percentage, say 50.0 means 50%. Must be >=0.0 Lower bound = (Normal Density) - (Normal Density)*Tolerance Upper bound = (Normal Density) + (Normal Density)*Tolerance
member.remarks:
There are six cases to consider:
======== ==== ============= ======================================== Case Flag Solutions Symptoms ======== ==== ============= ======================================== CASE 1A: 0 No correction Recorded and actual Line lengths same Reading densities vary slightly (passed the tolerance test) -------- ---- ------------- ---------------------------------------- CASE 1B -1 No correction Line lengths same Reading densities vary and cannot pass the tolerance test -------- ---- ------------- ---------------------------------------- CASE 2A 1 Corrected by Recorded line length too short extension Possible high readings in segment(s) Corrected (by extending) and actual lengths become the same -------- ---- ------------- ---------------------------------------- CASE 2B 2 Corrected by Recorded line length too short interpolation Possible high readings in segment(s) Corrected (by extending) and actual lengths are not same. Interpolation is then applied -------- ---- ------------- ---------------------------------------- CASE 3A 1 Corrected by Recorded line length too long shifting or Possible low readings in segment(s) (shrank) Corrected (by shifting) and actual lengths are same -------- ---- ------------- ---------------------------------------- CASE 3B 2 Corrected by Recorded line length too long interpolation Possible low readings in segment(s) Corrected (by shifting) and actual lengths are not same. Interpolation is then applied ======== ==== ============= ========================================
TERMINOLOGY:
Segments A segment refers to the distance and its contents between two adjacent fiducial markers
Normal Density The density (number of readings) shared by the segments in a survey line. The number of segments with the density is greater than the number of segments having a different density in a line.
Tolerance and Bound: Tolerance is defined as a percentage, say 50% (=0.5). Based on the tolerance, a lower bound and upper bound
can be defined:
::
Lower bound = (Normal Density) - (Normal Density)*Tolerance Upper bound = (Normal Density) - (Normal Density)*Tolerance
Segments will pass the tolerance test if the number of readings falls within the Lower and Upper Bounds.

member.summary: Load and return handle to a convolution filter.

Terminates process if filter not found. A filter file is an ASCII file that contains filter coefficients, which are simply mumbers. There can be one coefficient to a line. Blank lines and comment lines are skipped. Comment lines beginn with a forward slash character in column 1. Following is an example Fraser Filter file:
/---------------------- / Fraser Filter /---------------------- -1 -1 1 1

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CEXP.CreateFile(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.String)
member.summary: This method creates an EXP object from a file

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CEXP.Create(GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CDB,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: This method creates an EXP object.
member.remarks:
Expressions are strings that contain C-like math to be applied to channels in a database. For example, following an expression:
::
"@a = mag-64000; @b = gravity*100; $sRatio = @a/@b; MULT = @a *@b;"
Rules:
; terminates a sub-expression
@ prefix to a temporary name, which is a double precision floating point number to be used later in the same expression.
$ prefix to a local GX variable name. Such names will be evaluated to the variable value at the time Create_EXP is called.
All other tokens are assumed to be channel names.

member.name: T:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CEXP
member.summary: EXP objects are created from text strings that contain C-like math to be applied to channels in a database. It is used with the Math_DU function (see DU). See also IEXP for applying math expressions to images (grids). See also Math_DU applies expressions to the database

member.param: Solution type flag (0 for contacts, 1 for dykes)
Structural index value (used only when generating dykes)
Array of point distances along profile
Array of horizontal derivative values. Can be NULL for calculated
Array of vertical derivative values. Can be NULL for calculated
Length of solutions arrays passed in
The profile distance for each solution

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CEMAP.iGetRect(System.String,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Returns the coordinates of a user selected box starting at a corner.
member.param: X minimum in current view user units. (defines corner)
member.remarks: The coordinates are returned in the current User projection (See GetUserIPJ_MVIEW and SetUserIPJ_MVIEW.) If the user IPJ distorts the coordinates from being rectilinear (e.g. for a TriPlot graph), then care should be taken since the (Xmin, Ymin) and (Xmax, Ymax) values returned do not necessarily correspond to the lower-left and upper-right corners. In fact, the returned values are calculated by taking the starting (fixed) corner and the tracked (opposite) corner, and finding the min and max for X and Y among these two points. With a warped User projection, those two corner locations could easily be (Xmin, Ymax) and (Xmax, Ymin). This becomes quite important if you want to use the rectangle for a masking operation, because the "other" two corner's coordinates may need to be constructed based on a knowledge of the User projection, and may not be directly obtained from the returned X and Y min and max values. What appears to be a rectangle as seen on the map is not necessarily a rectangle in the User coordinates.
member.returns: 0 if point returned. 1 if user cancelled.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CEMAP.iGetPolyLineXYZ(System.String,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV,GeoEngine.Core.GXNet.CVV)
member.remarks: The coordinates are returned in the current User projection (See GetUserIPJ_MVIEW and SetUserIPJ_MVIEW.) In this version of the method X, Y and Z (depth) are returned. Initially created to deal with crooked sections.
member.returns: 0 if line returned. 1 if user cancelled.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CEMAP.iGetGrid(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Position and size a grid on a map.
member.param: Number of elements along primary axis to draw.
Number of elements along secondary axis to draw.
Angle of primary axis in degrees
member.remarks: If the input angle is <define>rDUMMY</define>, an extra step is inserted for the user to define the angle by drawing a line with the mouse. The output primary axis angle will always be in the range -90 < angle <= 90. The grid origin is shifted to whichever corner necessary to make this possible, while keeping the secondary axis at 90 degrees greater than the primary ( going counter-clockwise). The coordinates are returned in the current User projection (See GetUserIPJ_MVIEW and SetUserIPJ_MVIEW.)
member.returns: 0 if line returned. 1 if user cancelled.

member.name: M:Geosoft.Desktop.GXNet.CEMAP.iGetBox2(System.String,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Returns the coordinates of a user selected box in a warped view.
member.remarks: If the data view has a rotational (or other) warp, then the iGetBox_EMAP function returns only opposite diagonal points in the box, not enough info to determine the other two corners. This function returns the exact coordinates of all four corners, calculated from the pixel locations.
member.returns: 0 if point returned. 1 if user cancelled.
